thread.title: Giants good, bad and ugly: What the 30-27 win over San Francisco 49ers says about team
thread.title_full: Giants good, bad and ugly: What the 30-27 win over San Francisco 49ers says about team | NJ.com

author: Jordan Raanan | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Giants good, bad and ugly: What the 30-27 win over San Francisco 49ers says about team
text:
EAST RUTHERFORD -- With a chance to grab sole possession of first place in the NFC East, the Giants almost failed to take advantage of an inferior San Francisco 49ers team, in part because the Giants barely had enough healthy wide receivers to field an offensive unit on the game's final drive.
But, with Odell Beckham Jr. returning from a hamstring injury -- that he might have suffered on a touchdown celebration dance -- to draw a key pass-interference penalty on the final drive, the Giants rallied in the waning seconds for a dramatic 30-27 victory over the 49ers at MetLife Stadium on Sunday night.
One play after Beckham draw the flag, quarterback Eli Manning threw a 12-yard touchdown pass to leaping tight end Larry Donnell in the back of the end zone with 21 seconds remaining.
It's a referendum on this Giants team, which is 3-2 and sitting atop the NFC East after an 0-2 start. The Giants may not be great or dominant, but they're good enough to beat inferior competition.
POLITI: It's time for Beckham to stop the nonsense
After opening the season with meltdown losses to the Cowboys and Falcons, the Giants dominated the Washington Redskins, 32-21, at home in Week 3, took care of a sloppy Bills team, 24-10, in Week 4 and did enough to beat the 49ers.
These are your 2015 Giants. They could have been 5-0, but they have heart. They never give up. And they make things interesting.
The Good
The Giants moved the ball up and down the field all evening, even with a depleted receiving corps. Manning threw for over 441 yards and three touchdowns. The Giants punted just twice.
And when they needed it most, Manning -- who threw an end zone interception with five seconds remaining in the first half -- drove the Giants for the winning score. The Giants went 81 yards in 1:20, with Donnell making a leaping touchdown grab over two defenders with 21 seconds remaining.
The Giants' offense (minus red zone stumbles) was in sync.
The Bad
The Giants defense yielded 27 points to a struggling offense, mostly because the pass rush couldn't get near San Francisco quarterback Colin Kaepernick most of the evening. If Kaepernick and the 49ers weren't ranked No. 32 in passing offense, the Giants would've been in trouble. Still, Kaepernick threw for 250 yards and two touchdowns.
The Giants best pass rusher again appeared to be 245-pound fullback/defensive tackle Nikita Whitlock. He forced a holding penalty on a third-quarter play. That may have been the closest the Giants came to Kaepernick in the second half.
The Ugly
The Giants had a chance for points at the end of the first half. With a chance to take a commanding lead, they were at the San Francisco 11-yard line with 11 seconds remaining and a 13-6 edge. The only thing the Giants couldn't afford was a turnover. What did they do? The NFL's No. 31-ranked red zone offense turned it over when Manning threw a poor pass in the right corner of the end zone to a Beckham, who was covered, and the pass was intercepted by 49ers cornerback Tramaine Brock.
